newsitem.title: USA: Stocks rally, bonds firmer, dollar mixed.
newsitem.headline: Stocks rally, bonds firmer, dollar mixed.

text.p: Stocks rallied on Thursday, while bonds edged higher on economic news that reduced chances of an interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve.
The dollar was mixed.

The Dow Jones industrial average ended up 58.35 points at 7,777.06, standing just below its record closing high of 7,782.04 set on June 13. The 30-stock blue chip index rallied briefly through 7,800 for the first time, peaking at 7,810.54 before settling back.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks and the NYSE Composite index of all listed common stocks both set records.
In the broader market, advancing issues swamped declines 1,739 to 783 on active volume of 536 million on the New York Stock Exchange.
The market also was propelled by an upbeat forecast by Prudential Securities' well-known market bull, Ralph Acampora, who raised his targets for the Dow to 10,000 in the next year.

Investors were already cheering a narrower-than-expected April trade deficit and news that exports jumped to a record high, despite a strong dollar, as well as a surprising jump in weekly jobless claims. The developments were expected to deter the Federal Reserve from moving toward an interest rate rise at its policy-setting meeting in July.

"There's a lot of buying momentum out there. (Acampora) just keeps on increasing his numbers. That creates a very strong bullish feeling on Wall Street," said Warren Epstein, director of trading at Richard Rosenblatt.

Acampora, Prudential Securities' director of technical research, advised people to "Remain fully invested -- we expect the stock market to mount an explosive advance during the second half of the year," he wrote in a report.
Weekly jobless claims rose to 347,000 in the latest week from 339,000 a week earlier, suggesting that the red-hot labour market might be cooling.

The government also said the trade deficit rose 7.8 percent in April to $8.4 billion but noted that exports hit a record level. That could mean bigger profits ahead for U.S. companies who do business abroad, analysts said.

Traders said stocks also benefited from a burst of buying prior to Friday's "triple witching" expiration of futures and options. Some investors who had bet that stocks would fall had to cover their bets and buy them back, even in a rising market.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 8.93 points to 897.99, a record. The NYSE Composite index of all listed common stocks rose 4.35 to 467.76, a new high.

In the bond market, the 30-year Treasury bond edged up 3/32, or 93.75 cents on a $1,000 bond, reducing its yield to 6.68 percent from 6.69 percent at Wednesday's close. The price and the yield move in opposite directions.
The dollar rose to 114.03 Japanese yen late Thursday from 113.65 yen late Wednesday. It fell to 1.7235 German marks from 1.7333 marks.
Rice futures rose sharply in heavy volume amid growing concern about the impact of the developing El Nino weather pattern off western South America on crops in Asia.

For the second consecutive session, almost all delivery months for rice made life-of-contract highs at the Chicago Board of Trade. The exception, July, rose to a two-month peak of $11.90 per hundred pounds before closing 8.5 cents higher at $11.75.

Wheat futures fell to a 4-1/2 month low of $3.36 as early reports on this year's harvest continued to suggest better- than-expected yields. Wheat for July delivery on the CBOT closed 1-3/4 cents lower at $3.37 a bushel.

Corn prices kept falling on nearly ideal crop weather in the key growing states of the U.S. Midwest. The key new crop delivery month, December, tumbled to a life-of-contract low of $2.43-1/4 and closed down 1-3/4 cents at $2.43-1/2.
Overseas, London's FTSE 100 share fell for the fourth day in a rowm, ending down 3.3 points at 4,653.7. In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 ended 10 points higher at 20,507.85.
